content: The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 is established to set federal guidelines for electronic voting equipment. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 establishes federal guidelines for electronic voting equipment, including specific guidelines for the operation of electronic voting equipment in elections for Federal office. These guidelines ensure that the equipment complies with technologies that allow a contemporaneous, redundant, and auditable trail of the votes cast. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 sets federal guidelines for electronic voting equipment, ensuring a contemporaneous, redundant, and auditable trail of votes. It also requires technology for voter verification, equipment security, and accessibility for individuals with disabilities. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 mandates the National Institute of Standards and Technology to provide technical support for developing guidelines for electronic voting equipment. The Director must complete the requirements by January 1, 2010. States are required to meet the guidelines outlined in the Act. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 mandates that electronic voting equipment must meet specific guidelines set by the Commission. This includes requirements for electronic vote recording and tabulation devices. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 mandates specific guidelines for electronic voting equipment, including requirements for vote recording devices. Funding of $1 billion for meeting these requirements is allocated for fiscal year 2011 and onwards. The Voting Enhancement and Security Act of 2007 allocates $1 billion for states to meet requirements for electronic voting equipment, including modifying or replacing voting systems in response to the guidelines. SEC. 3. REQUIRING AUDITS OF RESULTS OF ELECTIONS. This section amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to require states to conduct audits of election results. Each State must conduct audits of election results for Federal office in accordance with a State audit plan, detailing the responsible entity, procedures, rules for selecting audited elections, and number of tabulation units involved. A tabulation unit is defined as a pre-established unit where votes can be compared with audit results. The State must submit its initial audit plan to the Commission by January 1, 2009, ensuring fair and transparent procedures for auditing election results. This section applies to general elections starting in November 2010. Enforcement availability under Section 401 of the Act is also amended. The U.S.C. 15511 is amended to replace "sections 301, 302, and 303" with "subtitle A of title III". A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents of the Act. SEC. 4. REQUIRING STATES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ELECTION SECURITY PROTOCOLS AND CONTINGENCY PLANS. Amends the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to include a new section on the development and implementation of election security protocols and contingency plans. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to require States to develop and implement security protocols and contingency plans for elections for Federal office, effective from the 2008 general election onwards.
